case_name: Review Petition Crl. No.19 of 1974 in Criminal Appeal No. 70 of 1972

facts.text: Review Petition Crl. No.19 of 1974 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Review Petition  Crl.  No.19 of 1974. Application for review-of the Courts Judgment dated the 9th January, 1974 in. Criminal Appeal No. 70 of 1972.

facts.text: Application for review of the Court's Judgment dated 9th January 1974 in Criminal Appeal No. 70 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Application for review-of the Courts Judgment dated the 9th January, 1974 in. Criminal Appeal No. 70 of 1972. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th September, 1971 of the Patna High Court at Patna in Criminal Appeal No. 90 of 1968 Jethmalani, S. N. Misra and S.S. Jauhar for the Petitioner.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from Judgment and Order dated 16th September 1971 of Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 90 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th September, 1971 of the Patna High Court at Patna in Criminal Appeal No. 90 of 1968 Jethmalani, S. N. Misra and S.S. Jauhar for the Petitioner. C. Prasad, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BEG J.-This is an application for review Of an order passed by us on 19-1-1974 on a Criminal Appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Applicant Sawal Das tried together with father Jamuna Prasad and step-mother Kalawati Devi for murder of his wife Chanda Devi.

anchor.surface_text: The applicant had been tried, together with his father Jamuna Prasad and step-mother Kalawati Devi, and convicted for the murder of his wife Chanda Devi, who, it was alleged, had frequent quarrels with Kalawati. The applicant and his father and certain other persons were also charged under Section 201 Indian Penal Code for disposing of the body of Chanda Devi after the murder knowing that .she bad been murdered.

facts.text: Chanda Devi had frequent quarrels with Kalawati.

anchor.surface_text: his wife Chanda Devi, who, it was alleged, had frequent quarrels with Kalawati. The applicant and his father and certain other persons were also charged under Section 201 Indian Penal Code for disposing of the body of Chanda Devi after the murder knowing that .she bad been murdered.

facts.text: Applicant, father and others charged under Section 201 IPC for disposing of body of Chanda Devi knowing she had been murdered.

anchor.surface_text: The applicant and his father and certain other persons were also charged under Section 201 Indian Penal Code for disposing of the body of Chanda Devi after the murder knowing that .she bad been murdered. The Trial Court convicted the applicant Sawal Das, his father JAmuna Prasad, and his step-mother Kalawati for the offence of murder under Section 302 read with Section 34 I. C.

facts.text: Trial Court convicted Sawal Das, Jamuna Prasad and Kalawati under Section 302/34 IPC and sentenced each to rigorous imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court convicted the applicant Sawal Das, his father JAmuna Prasad, and his step-mother Kalawati for the offence of murder under Section 302 read with Section 34 I. C. and sentenced each of them to rigorous imprisonment for life. The applicant and his father were also convicted under Section 201 1. P. C.

facts.text: Applicant and father convicted under Section 201 IPC but no separate sentences imposed.

anchor.surface_text: The applicant and his father were also convicted under Section 201 1. P. C. but no separate sentences were imposed uPon them for this offence In view of the fact that they had been sentenced under Sections 304/34 1. P. C.

facts.text: High Court set aside convictions of Kalawati for both offences and ordered her set at liberty.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on an appeal by convicted persons, set aside the convictions of Kalawati for both offences and ordered her to be set at liberty. It also allowed the appeal of Jamuna Prasad the father of the applicant to the extent that it set aside his conviction under Sections 302/34 1. P. C., but it maintained his conviction under Section 201 I. P. C.

facts.text: High Court set aside Jamuna Prasad's conviction under 302/34 IPC but maintained conviction under 201 IPC and sentenced to 3 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: It also allowed the appeal of Jamuna Prasad the father of the applicant to the extent that it set aside his conviction under Sections 302/34 1. P. C., but it maintained his conviction under Section 201 I. P. C. and sentenced him to three years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: High Court converted Sawal Das's conviction from 302/34 to 302 IPC simpliciter and maintained life imprisonment sentence.

anchor.surface_text: It converted the conviction of the applicant under Section 302/34 I. P. C. to a conviction under Section 302 I. P. C. simpliciter and maintained the sentence of life imprisonment in the following terms The appeal of appellant Sawal Das is dismissed maintaining his conviction and sentence under Section 201, Indian Penal Code and also maintaining the sentence upon him for the offence of murder but altering the conviction from Section 302/ 34, to 302, Indian Penal Code simpliciter.

facts.text: High Court maintained Sawal Das's conviction and sentence under Section 201 IPC to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences will run concurrently as already decided by the Court below. Apparently, the High Court was under the erroneous impression that the applicant Sawal Das had been not only convicted but also sentenced by the Trial Court under Section 302 1. P. C. as well as under Section 201 I. P. C.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed Jamuna Prasad's application for leave to appeal against conviction under Section 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: This Court dismissed the application of applicants father Jamuna Prasad for leave to appeal against his conviction and sentence under Section 201 I. P. C. It also refused leave to the applicant to contest any point beyond the correctness of his conviction and sentence under Section 302 1. P. C.

facts.text: Supreme Court refused leave to applicant to contest points beyond conviction under Section 302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It also refused leave to the applicant to contest any point beyond the correctness of his conviction and sentence under Section 302 1. P. C. This Court, after having considered the uncertainties, arising from the facts found, as to whether all the three persons accused of murder or only one of then, committed. acts which could fasten the liablility for murder upon him or her sing y,

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside applicant's conviction under Section 302 IPC due to uncertainty under Section 34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: came to the conclusion that the applicant must get the benefit of that uncertainty as the charge under Section 34 1. P. C. had failed. It could not be definitely said whether the applicant had actually taken part, and, if so, what that was,, in murdering his wife Chanda Devi.

facts.text: Murder of Chanda Devi was committed after applicant, father and step-mother were seen following her into a room.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless, this Court was convinced that a murder of Chanda Devi had been committed after the applicant, his father, and his step-mother were seen following her into a room in their house. No one had said what actually took place inside it.

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed applicant's conviction under Section 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: As a necessary consequence of setting aside the conviction of the applicant under Section 302 I.P.C. while affirming this conviction under Section 201 I.P.C., as nospecial leave to appeal was granted against this conviction,this Court had to disposed the case by parking some order on the sentence under Section 201 I.P.C.

facts.text: Supreme Court order passed on 19-1-1974 on Criminal Appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BEG J.-This is an application for review Of an order passed by us on 19-1-1974 on a Criminal Appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court imposes 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine on applicant under Section 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We do not find sufficient grounds for revising the sentence of 7 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs.

facts.text: No one stated what took place inside the room.

anchor.surface_text: No one had said what actually took place inside it. As a necessary consequence of setting aside the conviction of the applicant under Section 302 I.P.C. while affirming this conviction under Section 201 I.P.C.,

facts.text: Trial Court sentenced under Sections 302/34 IPC without separate sentence for 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court, as already observed, had neither passed a separate sentence under Section 201 I. P. C. upon the appli- cant nor indicated what it could be. It overlooked that, according to law, a separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if sentences are made concurrent

issues.text: Whether the Supreme Court could impose a sentence under Section 201 IPC upon the applicant given that no separate sentence was passed by the Trial Court or High Court and no appeal was filed by the State against such failure

anchor.surface_text: The applicant has come up on a technical point. It is that, as no appeal was filed at all by the State against the failure of the Trial Court to pass a separate sentence under Section 201 I.P.C., or against the failure of the High Court to specify the sentence on the erroneous assumption that some sentence had actually been passed for an offence under Section 201 I.P.C. upon the applicant, this

issues.text: Whether a conviction for an offence can be sustained without the imposition of a sentence thereon

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the applicant brought to our notice Jayaram Vithoba Anr. v. The State of Bambay 1  which was a case under the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act. This. Court had laid down there  at p. 1054- 55  When a person is tried for an offence and convicted, it is the duty of the Court to impose on him such sentence, as is prescribed therefor. The law does number envisage a person being convicted for an offence without a sentence being imposed therefor.

issues.text: Whether an appellate court has the power under Section 423(1)(d) CrPC to impose a sentence as a consequential or incidental order when affirming a conviction but no sentence was awarded by the trial court
Whether a separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if the sentences are to run concurrently

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court, as already observed, had neither passed a separate sentence under Section 201 I. P. C. upon the appli- cant nor indicated what it could be. It overlooked that, according to law, a separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if sentences are made concurrent

issues.text: Whether the applicant was heard on the question of sentence to be imposed under Section 201 IPC

arguments.claim: As no appeal was filed by the State against the failure of the Trial Court to pass a separate sentence under Section 201 IPC or the High Court's failure to specify the sentence, this Court could not pass any sentence under Section 201 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The applicant has come up on a technical point. arguments.court_reasoning: Appellate court has power under CrPC s.423(1)(d) to impose consequential sentence upon affirming conviction without prior sentence; conviction requires sentence per precedent

arguments.claim: When a person is tried for an offence and convicted, it is the duty of the Court to impose sentence; law does not envisage conviction without sentence

Court had laid down there  at p. 1054- 55  When a person is tried for an offence and convicted, it is the duty of the Court to impose on him such sentence, as is prescribed therefor. The law does

arguments.claim: Appellate court power preserved under section 423(1)(d) CrPC to make consequential or incidental order including imposing sentence when affirming conviction but no prior sentence
View in Ibrahim v Emperor that imposing sentence without prior award is enhancement is incorrect; consequential order can be passed

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view .expressed in Ibrahim v. Emperor  AIR 1940 Bom. 129  that such an order would be an enhancement of the sentence. We think that what was held in the case cited above applies to the case before us also.

arguments.claim: Applicant was convicted under Section 201 IPC and sentence ordered to run concurrently; only period not fixed, which required fixing after setting aside 302 sentence
Court had not heard the applicant on the question of sentence under Section 201 IPC
arguments.court_reasoning: Applicant was heard in original judgment and again on review after notice to State

arguments.claim: Separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if concurrent, as conviction for one may be set aside

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court, as already observed, had neither passed a separate sentence under Section 201 I. P. C. upon the appli- cant nor indicated what it could be. It overlooked that, according to law, a separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if sentences are made concurrent

holdings.text: according to law, a separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if sentences are made concurrent because a Court may, as it has in this case, set aside a conviction so that the need for a separate sentence must necessarily arise in such an event.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court, as already observed, had neither passed a separate sentence under Section 201 I. P. C. upon the appli- cant nor indicated what it could be. It overlooked that, according to law, a separate sentence ought to be passed for each offence even if sentences are made concurrent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial Court erred by not passing separate sentence; required by law to avoid issues when one conviction is set aside leaving others.

holdings.text: When a person is tried for an offence and convicted, it is the duty of the Court to impose on him such sentence, as is prescribed therefor. The law does not envisage a person being convicted for an offence without a sentence being imposed therefor.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the applicant brought to our notice Jayaram Vithoba Anr. v. The State of Bambay 1  which was a case under the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act. This. Court had laid down there  at p. 1054- 55  When a person is tried for an offence and convicted, it is the duty of the Court to impose on him such sentence, as is prescribed therefor. The law does

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Supreme Court precedent in Jayaram Vithoba that conviction mandates imposition of sentence.

holdings.text: this power is preserved to the appellate court, expressly by section 423 (1) d which enacts that it can make any amendment or any consequential or incidental order that may be just or proper. When a conviction is affirmed in appeal but no sentence had been awarded by the trial Magistrate, the award of a sentence is consequential on and incidental to the affirmance of the conviction, and it is a just and proper order to be passed under the law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of CrPC s.423(1)(d) empowers appellate court to pass consequential sentence upon affirming conviction lacking sentence.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with the view expressed in Ibrahim v. Emperor that such an order would be an enhancement of the sentence.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view .expressed in Ibrahim v. Emperor  AIR 1940 Bom. 129  that such an order would be an enhancement of the sentence. We think that what was held in the case cited above applies to the case before us also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Ibrahim v Emperor; imposing initial sentence is not enhancement but consequential order.

holdings.text: The contention of the applicant that, as no particular sentence was imposed by the High Court or the Trial Court, the applicant must be deemed not to have been sentenced at all is also incorrect. The orders passed show that the applicant was not only convicted under Section 201 I.P.C. but his sentence for the offence was ordered to run concurrently with the life sentence. Only the period of the sentence was not fixed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court ordered concurrent sentence under s.201, merely period unfixed; fixing it consequential after setting aside life sentence.

holdings.text: We find, from our judgment, that this was done. However, we have heard the applicant again on this review application after issuing notice to the State.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Record shows applicant heard originally on sentence; reheard on review after notice.

holdings.text: We do not find sufficient grounds for revising the sentence of 7 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs.

anchor.surface_text: We do not find sufficient grounds for revising the sentence of 7 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review application lacks merit; original sentence under s.201 upheld after hearing.
